etymology.description: semantic 言(言) (yán, "speech") + phonetic 兌(兌) (duì, "exchange") = speech action -> speak
etymology.interpretation: The character 說(說) combines 言(言) (yán, "speech") indicating a verbal action, with 兌(兌) (duì, "exchange"), suggesting the idea of exchanging words or speaking. This phono-semantic composition intuitively represents the act of speaking or communicating.
etymology.simplification: Simplified to 说(說), where 訁(言) (yán, "speech") is replaced with 讠(讠) (yán, "speech"), a cursive shorthand form, to reduce the number of strokes.

examples.chinese: 妈妈对我说(媽媽對我說)，要好好学习(要好好學習)。
examples.pinyin: Māmā duì wǒ shuō, yào hǎohǎo xuéxí.
examples.english: Mom told me to study hard.
